choices.C: disable FTP access to the wancom0 management interface
choices.B: know the superuser mode password and access the configuration mode
choices.E: verify the configuration by executing the verify-config command

discussion.content: Correct answer is B. You must enter configuration mode to change bootparam

questions.question_text: What is the first thing you must do when setting up the boot parameters of the Session Border Controller?

choices.E: Navigate to the session-agent configuration element and set the strategy parameter to leastbusy.
choices.A: Navigate to the session-agent configuration element and set the strategy parameter to sequential.
choices.D: Navigate to the session-agent configuration element and set the strategy parameter to roundrobin.
choices.B: Navigate to the session-agent configuration element and set the strategy parameter to propdist.
choices.C: Navigate to the session-agent configuration element and set the strategy parameter to hunt.

questions.question_text:
You configured the Session Agent Group (SAG) element. You want the Session Agent to be selected in the order in which they are listed in the destination list, with each agent selected in turn, one per session.
How would you accomplish this?

discussion.content:
Correct D
RoundRobin—Selects each session agent in the order in which they are listed in the dest list, selecting each agent in turn, one per session. After all session agents have been used, the first session agent is used again and the cycle continues.
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E97662_01/html/sbc_scz820_aclireference/GUID-FAE74801-733A-45C8-9830-801E6E09D085.htm#GUID-FAE74801-733A-45C8-9830-801E6E09D085

questions.question_text:
When provisioning the redundancy-configuration, the peer name for each of the peers in a High Availability configuration must also be defined in each systems
______________.

discussion.content:
Correct answer is D.

HA Node Peer Configuration To configure a Oracle® Enterprise Session Border Controller as an HA node peer: 1. From the redundancy menu, type peers and press Enter. ORACLE(system)# redundancy ORACLE(redundancy)# peers 2. state—Enable or disable HA for this Oracle® Enterprise Session Border Controller. The default value is enabled. The valid values are: • enabled | disabled 3. name—Set the name of the HA node peer as it appears in the target name boot parameter. This is also the name of your system that appears in the system prompt. For example, in the system prompt ORACLE1#, ORACLE1 is the target name for that Oracle® Enterprise Session Border Controller

choices.B: hostname parameter under the account-config configuration element
choices.E: hostname parameter under the system-config configuration element
choices.C: hostname parameter under the bootparam configuration branch
choices.A: hostname parameter under the sip-config configuration element
choices.D: target name parameter under the bootparam configuration branch

choices.C: From superuser mode, execute the save-config and activate-config and reboot commands.
choices.E: From superuser mode, execute the save-config, activate-config, and reboot force commands.
choices.B: From configuration mode, execute the save-config, activate-config, and reboot commands.
choices.A: From user mode, execute the save-config and activate-config commands.
choices.D: From superuser mode, execute the save-config and activate-config commands.

discussion.content:
Being not RTC, correct answers are C and E (i.e. you need to reboo).
These commands have to be issued from superuser mode.

questions.question_text:
You finished configuring a not Real Time Change (not RTC)-supported configuration element and you want to apply the change in your service.
Which two options are valid in order to accomplish this? (Choose two.)
How does the Session Border Controller ensure that a pinhole is kept open for persistent communication to a SIP endpoint behind a NAT device?

discussion.content: correct answer is E (sent message is OPTION)

comments.content:
Correct answer is A.
SIP OPTIONs are used on Dynamic Hosted NAT Traversal. But the SBC will still change the value of the "expire" header on the 200 OK of the REGISTER to force the endpoint to re-register after a short period of time.

choices.B: by changing the expires= parameter to a defined value in 200 OK responses to INVITEs
choices.C: by issuing PINGs to the endpoint's NAT address
choices.E: by sending messages at a defined frequency
choices.D: by sending Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) requests at a defined frequency
choices.A: by changing the expires= parameter to a defined value in 200 OK responses to REGISTERs
